description.narrative: An effective multiple use forest governance system is in operation resulting in enhanced biodiversity and maintained landscape level ecosystem functions, integrity and resilience for the Caspian Hyrcanian forests of Iran
seat of a second-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Project pilot site of Baliran in Amol, Mazandaran Province

description.narrative: seat of a second-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Project pilot site of Chehel Chay in Minudasht, Golestan Province

description.narrative: seat of a second-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Project pilot site of Fariroud-Zilakiroud in Rudbar and Siahkal, Gilan Province

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: An enabling policy and regulatory framework for multiple use forest management is developed
Extent of integration of ecosystem values into production sector strategies and plans

comment.narrative: Ecosystem goods and services are utilised by production sectors however their true ecological value is not understood or incorporated into the economics of key production sectors
Systematic analysis of values of forests and externalities of deforestation and forest degradation incorporated into sector decisions and finance options identified to offset opportunity costs

Ecosystem services in pilot landscapes have been mapped by application of a novel tool called InVest software The software is used for the first time ever in the country which offers visual understanding of ecosystem services in two scenarios of present and future The future scenario can be used as a supporting tool for decision making in pilot landscapes economic values of ecosystem services are being calculated which will be followed by designing of financial options under Payment for Ecosystem Services PES The whole set of study is being conducted by a team of national consultants and supervision of international consultant The study will be finalized by Q2 2016 The study has been involving relevant stakeholders mainly Government entities in training and consultation sessions and helped a lot in raising the awareness an building capacities on ecosystem services and their economic values
Systematic analysis of values of forests and externalities of deforestation and forest degradation incorporated into sector decisions and finance options identified to offset opportunity costs

Ecosystem services in pilot landscapes have been mapped by application of a novel tool called InVest software The software is used for the first time ever in the country which offers visual understanding of ecosystem services in two scenarios of present and future The future scenario can be used as a supporting tool for decision making in pilot landscapes economic values of ecosystem services are being calculated which will be followed by designing of financial options under Payment for Ecosystem Services PES The whole set of study is being conducted by a team of national consultants and supervision of international consultant The study will be finalized by Q2 2016 The study has been involving relevant stakeholders mainly Government entities in training and consultation sessions and helped a lot in raising the awareness an building capacities on ecosystem services and their economic values

description.narrative: INTERSECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED National policy and regulatory framework is adjusted to meet BD mainstreaming requirements and is updated within operational procedures

comment.narrative: FRWO and other FMPs are not coordinated and lack inclusion of biodiversity conservation practices

INTERSECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED AT HYRCANIAN FOREST AND PILOT LANDSCAPE LEVELS
1 FRWO regulation on multiple use planning issued

Local Coordination Committees LCCs have been regularly meeting on a quarterly basis as the main intersectoral coordination mechanism at the local level LCCs have been heavily involved in development of Integrated Management Plans IMPs which ensures functioning of the mechanism Regional Coordination Committee RCC was established as the main driver for intersectoral and interprovincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests The latter makes sure a harmonized approach between all three Caspian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape through development and implementation of the so called Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy The Strategy is under preparation after the first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline Implementation of the Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme The study on policies laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015

INTERSECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED AT HYRCANIAN FOREST AND PILOT LANDSCAPE LEVELS
1 FRWO regulation on multiple use planning issued

Local Coordination Committees LCCs have been regularly meeting on a quarterly basis as the main intersectoral coordination mechanism at the local level LCCs have been heavily involved in development of Integrated Management Plans IMPs which ensures functioning of the mechanism Regional Coordination Committee RCC was established as the main driver for intersectoral and interprovincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests The latter makes sure a harmonized approach between all three Caspian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape through development and implementation of the so called Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy The Strategy is under preparation after the first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline Implementation of the Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme The study on policies laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015

description.narrative: Operational guidelines are being utilised to manage multiple land uses in forest landscapes including improved forestry small holder agriculture and livestock practices

comment.narrative: Forestry tourism and agriculture sectors lack a coordinated approach to management
At least 3 improved operational guidelines for i improved forestry ii sustainable small holder agriculture iii improved livestock practices and iv sustainable tourism

As the sectoral guidelines should encompass best practices and lessons learned preparation of these guidelines will be subject to slight postponement Development of guidelines starts in the second half of 2015 ToR for national coordinating consultant is drafted ad under finalization
At least 3 improved operational guidelines for i improved forestry ii sustainable small holder agriculture iii improved livestock practices and iv sustainable tourism

As the sectoral guidelines should encompass best practices and lessons learned preparation of these guidelines will be subject to slight postponement Development of guidelines starts in the second half of 2015 ToR for national coordinating consultant is drafted ad under finalization

description.narrative: INTEGRATED MULTIPURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN INCLUDING sustainable land use plan defines a clear direction for the Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and supports mainstreaming biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: Land use plans exist at the basincatchment levels under FRWO management and similar plans exist for DoE management of PAs However a coordinated plan for production sectors does not exist

INTEGRATED MULTIPURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN INCLUDING Sustainable land use plan for Caspian Hyrcanian forest that a define biodiversity rich areas to be gazetted as new PAs and b lay out appropriate landuses and management practices to be prescribed in the adjacent production landscape

To ensure intersectoral and interprovincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and adoption of a harmonized approach between all three Casian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape a so called Hyrcanian Forest Green Development Strategy is under preparation The first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline Implementation of the Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme The study on policies laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015 The Strategy will include a zoning plan for the whole Caspian area which will locate the main landuse categories across the whole region The Zoning Plan is also under preparation

INTEGRATED MULTIPURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN INCLUDING Sustainable land use plan for Caspian Hyrcanian forest that a define biodiversity rich areas to be gazetted as new PAs and b lay out appropriate landuses and management practices to be prescribed in the adjacent production landscape

To ensure intersectoral and interprovincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and adoption of a harmonized approach between all three Casian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape a so called Hyrcanian Forest Green Development Strategy is under preparation The first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline Implementation of the Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme The study on policies laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015 The Strategy will include a zoning plan for the whole Caspian area which will locate the main landuse categories across the whole region The Zoning Plan is also under preparation

description.narrative: Community based integrated forest management piloted
Number of community based forest management plans developed AGREED BY COMMUNITY MANAGEMENT COMMITTEES and implemented

comment.narrative: 2 COMMUNITY BASED FOREST MANAGEMENT PLANS COVERING 30000HA

FRWO has been practicing traditional forestry activities for several decades There are significant resistances against application of Community Forestry CF in technical and managerial disciplines of FRWO On the other hand local communities lack enough capacities to engage in CF planning and implementation The project has organized an introductory session on CF followed by a comprehensive training on this topic aiming at building capacities in FRWO for CF and reducing resistances Local communities have been aso exposed to the idea during the reporting period Its expected that development of CF plans will start towards the end of 2015 in limited areas first n Chehelchai and Sehezar pilots and then in Baliran In Fariroud Narvan cooperative is doing CF which needs adjustments to bring inclusiveness and equity There seem to be willingness to apply these amendments The project will start facilitation for these adjustments towards the end 2015
2 COMMUNITY BASED FOREST MANAGEMENT PLANS COVERING 30000HA

FRWO has been practicing traditional forestry activities for several decades There are significant resistances against application of Community Forestry CF in technical and managerial disciplines of FRWO On the other hand local communities lack enough capacities to engage in CF planning and implementation The project has organized an introductory session on CF followed by a comprehensive training on this topic aiming at building capacities in FRWO for CF and reducing resistances Local communities have been aso exposed to the idea during the reporting period Its expected that development of CF plans will start towards the end of 2015 in limited areas first n Chehelchai and Sehezar pilots and then in Baliran In Fariroud Narvan cooperative is doing CF which needs adjustments to bring inclusiveness and equity There seem to be willingness to apply these amendments The project will start facilitation for these adjustments towards the end 2015

description.narrative: Number of activities included in the alternative livelihood development strategy that are implemented and percentage increase in income of community groups

comment.narrative:
0
Income baseline of community groups will be established during the first year

At least 4 different types of alternative livelihood activities such as beekeeping NTFP enterprise rural handicrafts aquaculture dairy product marketing etc to be further selected from the PPG shortlist during IW
At least 1520 increase in income of targeted community groups

The alternative Livelihood Strategy is still under preparation in a consultative manner and based on indepth and comprehensive data and knowledge that the project gained in all four pilot landscapes Feasibility of low impact ecotourism is being assessed in all four pilots and the study is expected to come to an end in 3 months However alternative livelihood options is being taken in two of the pilot landscapes 6 women groups in Chehelchai are progressively making handicrafts and selling them under their name and brand Handicrafts are made from local materials and have roots in their culture Women groups have been able to generate significant amount of income as much as 5000 during the reporting period In project pilot landscape in Guilan Province two youth groups was established which are taking alternative options for income generation One group is developing its skills to do ecotourism activities The group has been able to take two groups of local tourists to the vicinity forest The other group tried to establish a nursery to produce seedlings of forest species Because of some legal challenges they have changed the idea and are trying to grow mushrooms as another alternative

At least 4 different types of alternative livelihood activities such as beekeeping NTFP enterprise rural handicrafts aquaculture dairy product marketing etc to be further selected from the PPG shortlist during IW
At least 1520 increase in income of targeted community groups

The alternative Livelihood Strategy is still under preparation in a consultative manner and based on indepth and comprehensive data and knowledge that the project gained in all four pilot landscapes Feasibility of low impact ecotourism is being assessed in all four pilots and the study is expected to come to an end in 3 months However alternative livelihood options is being taken in two of the pilot landscapes 6 women groups in Chehelchai are progressively making handicrafts and selling them under their name and brand Handicrafts are made from local materials and have roots in their culture Women groups have been able to generate significant amount of income as much as 5000 during the reporting period In project pilot landscape in Guilan Province two youth groups was established which are taking alternative options for income generation One group is developing its skills to do ecotourism activities The group has been able to take two groups of local tourists to the vicinity forest The other group tried to establish a nursery to produce seedlings of forest species Because of some legal challenges they have changed the idea and are trying to grow mushrooms as another alternative

description.narrative: Number of people shifting to alternative livelihood options that reduce pressure on biodiversity

comment.narrative: Baseline to be collected in Year 1
TARGET TO BE DEFINED IN 2014 AFTER DESIGN OF ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOODS PLAN

In total 8 groups of local communities 6 women groups and 2 youth groups started adoption of alternative livelihoods to reduce the pressure over forest landscapes Alternative Livelihood Strategy is under preparation and will be finalized in Q3 2015

description.narrative: The rate of forest clearance under CFM as compared against nonCFM areas

comment.narrative: Baseline to be measured for both CFM and nonCFM in 2014
Forest degradation due to agriculture illegal cutting and livestock grazing in community pilots decreased by at least 50 in total pilot area and less than nonCFM area
The baseline for forest clearance is under preparation through socioeconomic and forest condition assessment studies Both studies will be finalized by Q3 2015

comment.narrative: TBD 2014
PUBLIC AWARENESS INCREASES 20 OVERALL AND 50 IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

The awareness baseline is set for all four pilot landscapes vicinity downtowns and provincial capital cities The shift in the level of awareness will be measured at the end of the project implementation again compared to the baseline However the project has developed Communication and Awareness Raising Plan which is under implementation The project has launched a bilingual website 5 issues of newsletter 1 series 4 volumes of brochures on pilot landscapes and a number of other awareness raising materials

description.narrative: Number of training materials and best practices prepared and incorporated into FRWO management planning and induction courses

comment.narrative: At least 3

Project training plan is recently drafted 2 comprehensive trainings on social forestry and ecosystem services values have been offered during the reporting period Consultation sessions to develop IMPs SABs proposal and Social Forestry Roadmap have been conducted through which training and capacity building modules have been offered At least 300 people from different line sectors and local community representatives attended all these training and consultative sessions during the reporting period MoU is under finalization to be signed between the project and Training and Public Participation Bureau of FRWO for joint collaboration and inclusion of relevant trainings in the official induction and inservice training programmes of FRWO

description.narrative: Use of a functional and effective monitoring mechanism for community based illicit felling and land clearing

comment.narrative: Community based forests require support for monitoring
Effective monitoring systems in place to control harvesting forest resources

The study to review existing monitoring and enforcement mechanisms initiated and will be finalized in Q3 2015 The final conclusion of the study will be a number of proposals and a stepwise roadmap to adjust and amend existing mechanisms and make them more effective and aligned with multipurpose forest management requirements
Effective monitoring systems in place to control harvesting forest resources

The study to review existing monitoring and enforcement mechanisms initiated and will be finalized in Q3 2015 The final conclusion of the study will be a number of proposals and a stepwise roadmap to adjust and amend existing mechanisms and make them more effective and aligned with multipurpose forest management requirements

description.narrative: To put in place a collaborative governance system and knowhow for managing a mosaic of land uses in the Caspian Hyrcanian forest that provides habitat integrity and helps maintain landscape level ecosystem functions and resilience
Landscape area in the Caspian Hyrcanian forests where forestry and other production activities mainstream biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: 0 ha
Policy and regulatory frameworks for managing multiple use forest landscapes across 800000 ha of forests

Policy and regulatory frameworks have been reviewed through project financial resources to explore gaps for integration and mainstreaming of participatory multipurpose forestry and biodiversity conservation in sectoral policies laws and regulations as well as institutional mechanisms such as monitoring and law enforcement systems The study is at the final stages and its expected to suggest amendments to policies laws and regulations and institutional mechanisms The study suggests that there are almost no barrier in policies laws and regulatory frameworks to prevent FRWO and other government agencies to apply participatory forest management The study is also encouraging the parliament to approve the national Comprehensive Natural Resources Law which is awaiting the final steps in there A number of suggestions will come out of the study to enrich the regulatory framework of forest management These suggestions will go to the Forest High Council for further action and taking into practice In addition the project contributed to development of relevant articles of the 6th National Development Plan and incorporated participatory multipurpose forestry in its draft version as a mandate for all government sectors during 201620
Policy and regulatory frameworks for managing multiple use forest landscapes across 800000 ha of forests

Policy and regulatory frameworks have been reviewed through project financial resources to explore gaps for integration and mainstreaming of participatory multipurpose forestry and biodiversity conservation in sectoral policies laws and regulations as well as institutional mechanisms such as monitoring and law enforcement systems The study is at the final stages and its expected to suggest amendments to policies laws and regulations and institutional mechanisms The study suggests that there are almost no barrier in policies laws and regulatory frameworks to prevent FRWO and other government agencies to apply participatory forest management The study is also encouraging the parliament to approve the national Comprehensive Natural Resources Law which is awaiting the final steps in there A number of suggestions will come out of the study to enrich the regulatory framework of forest management These suggestions will go to the Forest High Council for further action and taking into practice In addition the project contributed to development of relevant articles of the 6th National Development Plan and incorporated participatory multipurpose forestry in its draft version as a mandate for all government sectors during 201620

description.narrative: Extent and quality of forest cover IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

comment.narrative:
Incidents of illicit felling involving creaming of commercially important species
Clearance of forest areas for agriculture leading to 05 loss of forests
No net loss of forest cover and improved quality with reduced loss of high grade species

Forest degradation is not only due to deforestation but also is mainly because of depletion of the forest quality There is no single indicator based on which one can assess the quality of forest Therefore further to conducting forest cover assessment through remote sensing methods the project arranged a comprehensive forest condition assessment through which 16 different forest parameters were measured The field study is finished and report writing is in final stages Forest quality parameters have been measured in pilot landscapes in the FRWO network of permanent monitoring plots with an area of 1000 square meters Forest cover and biodiversity parameters were also measured in the same network to be attributable The study will be repeated at the end of the project implementation for comparing results
No net loss of forest cover and improved quality with reduced loss of high grade species

Forest degradation is not only due to deforestation but also is mainly because of depletion of the forest quality There is no single indicator based on which one can assess the quality of forest Therefore further to conducting forest cover assessment through remote sensing methods the project arranged a comprehensive forest condition assessment through which 16 different forest parameters were measured The field study is finished and report writing is in final stages Forest quality parameters have been measured in pilot landscapes in the FRWO network of permanent monitoring plots with an area of 1000 square meters Forest cover and biodiversity parameters were also measured in the same network to be attributable The study will be repeated at the end of the project implementation for comparing results

description.narrative: STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

comment.narrative: SPECIES AND BASELINE TO BE SET IN 2014
NO DECLINE IN STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES BY END OF PROJECT

No change is expected to be measured in this stage Based on discussions with the biodiversity consultants as well as project CTA and approval of project board changes of biodiversity status and trends could not be measured in short periods Hence biodiversity survey will be repeated at the end of the project to assess the changes against the baseline Status of mammals is under study in all four pilot landscapes The study is focused on a few number of flagship species like Red Deer Roe Deer Persian Leopard Wolf Wild Boar and Brown Bear Mammals study is also addressing humanwildlife conflicts which is a very important cause for killing of animals and will be concluded with a plan for conflict resolution in each of the pilot landscapes
NO DECLINE IN STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES BY END OF PROJECT

No change is expected to be measured in this stage Based on discussions with the biodiversity consultants as well as project CTA and approval of project board changes of biodiversity status and trends could not be measured in short periods Hence biodiversity survey will be repeated at the end of the project to assess the changes against the baseline Status of mammals is under study in all four pilot landscapes The study is focused on a few number of flagship species like Red Deer Roe Deer Persian Leopard Wolf Wild Boar and Brown Bear Mammals study is also addressing humanwildlife conflicts which is a very important cause for killing of animals and will be concluded with a plan for conflict resolution in each of the pilot landscapes

description.narrative: Area of biodiversity setasides created governed by clear specific management guidelines

comment.narrative: Some areas 10 are under biodiversity setasides but without any systematic management regime for biodiversity conservation
At least 100000 ha of new biodiversity set asides under FRWO management defined with management guidelines

FRWO is managing Forest Reserves and Forest Parks in which rare plant species are conserved and protected The idea of BD Setasides puts forward a holistic mechanism through which both Fauna and Flora are under management regimes by FRWO Aiming at developing management regimes for better management of biodiversity in the whole Caspian Hyrcanina Area Special Areas for Biodiversity SABs will be established in consultation with FRWO technical divisions and DoE as the main relevant stakeholder SABs will be managed based on modern Biosphere Reserve model to ensure conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity Fauna and Flora A concept note has been developed on designing and management of SABs which was consulted in an inclusive biodiversity workshop Potential SABs have been initially mapped by relevant stakeholders and draft codes of practice prepared in a participatory manner Potential sites will be further studied and 100000 ha of area will be assigned and designated as SABs by Forest High Council by mid2016 Further steps will be taken to register SABs as biosphere reserves after the approval of the Forest HighCouncil
At least 100000 ha of new biodiversity set asides under FRWO management defined with management guidelines

FRWO is managing Forest Reserves and Forest Parks in which rare plant species are conserved and protected The idea of BD Setasides puts forward a holistic mechanism through which both Fauna and Flora are under management regimes by FRWO Aiming at developing management regimes for better management of biodiversity in the whole Caspian Hyrcanina Area Special Areas for Biodiversity SABs will be established in consultation with FRWO technical divisions and DoE as the main relevant stakeholder SABs will be managed based on modern Biosphere Reserve model to ensure conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity Fauna and Flora A concept note has been developed on designing and management of SABs which was consulted in an inclusive biodiversity workshop Potential SABs have been initially mapped by relevant stakeholders and draft codes of practice prepared in a participatory manner Potential sites will be further studied and 100000 ha of area will be assigned and designated as SABs by Forest High Council by mid2016 Further steps will be taken to register SABs as biosphere reserves after the approval of the Forest HighCouncil

description.narrative: 1. Landscape area in the Caspian Hyrcanian forests where forestry and other production activities mainstream biodiversity conservation 2. Area of biodiversity set-asides created governed by clear specific management guidelines 3. Improvement in Total Capacity Development Scorecard 4. Extent and quality of forest cover

comment.narrative: 1. 0 ha 2. Some areas (~ 10%) are under biodiversity set-asides but without any systematic management regime for biodiversity conservation 3. 10 4. Incidents of illicit felling involving creaming of commercially important species; Clearance of forest areas for agriculture leading to 0.5% loss of forests

1. At least 2 FMPs reviewed;
2. 1 FRWO regulation on multiple use planning approved
3. At least 3 improved operational guidelines for: i) improved forestry; ii) sustainable small holder agriculture; iii) improved livestock practices and iv) sustainable tourism
4. Green Development Strategy is approved, advocated to national and provincial stakeholders, and implementation launched.
5. Training modules on multi-purpose forestry developed for being used by CHFP
6. IMPs embedded in the work of the Provincial Planning and Development Councils and supported by LCCs and local IMP Secretariats

1. The FMP was developed based on the principles of CF with the participation of local communities in Baliran and Yuj.
2. The CF guideline was developed and approved by observing the principles of biodiversity.
3. Project achievements in the field of biodiversity, local communities' participation and alternative livelihoods and tourism were included and incorporated in the new FRWO guidelines.
4. the guideline for special areas of biodiversity (SABs) was prepared and approved and sent to the Guilan FRWO for implementation in the Farrirud and Zilakirud pilots.
5. "Community Forestry" and "Multi Purpose Forestry" guideline were developed and approved
6. CF training module, Training module on participation, Training module on ecotourism, Training module on biodiversity are 80% complete and will be submitted in 2019.
7. The IMPs were coordinated with the members of the Local Coordination Committee (LCC) with the annual plans of each sector, and most of the activities envisaged in the the annual local program and sent to the Provincial Planning and Development Council of the province (PPDC)
The project will go through closure activities
The project went through closure activities and closed successfully.
